title: Interactive Guide: From Drilldown to Dashboard

blocks.content: In this interactive guide, you’ll learn how to take a metric from Grafana Metrics Drilldown, refine it in Explore, and save the result to a dashboard for ongoing monitoring. This workflow helps you move seamlessly from investigation to a reusable visualization.
Open a metric visualization in Explore to examine and refine its underlying query. You can open a metric in Explore from the detailed view in Metrics Drilldown.

1. In the top-right corner of the visualization panel, click the Menu icon.
2. Select Explore.

Now that you've opened the metric in Explore, you can examine and refine its underlying query.



Examining a metric in Explore lets you better understand what data it’s returning and how it’s being queried. Refining the query helps you filter noise, adjust labels or time ranges, and ensure the metric accurately represents what you want to monitor.
Examine and refine the query in Code mode.
Switch to Builder mode for enhanced support with query writing.

Now that you've refined the query, it's time to add the metric to a dashboard. Adding a metric to a dashboard lets you monitor the metric over time without repeating the investigation. Dashboards make important signals easy to revisit, share with others, and track as conditions change.

Add the metric to a new dashboard.

1. From the toolbar at the top of the Explore page, click the Menu icon.
2. Select Add.
3. Select Add to dashboard.
4. Ensure that New dashboard is selected.
5. Click Open dashboard.
6. From the Dashboards page, enter a Title and Description for your dashboard panel and click Save.
7. In the Create Dashboard drawer, enter a for the new dashboard.
8. Optionally, enter a description.
9. Click Save.

blocks.title: Add the metric to a dashboard

blocks.content:
Nice work! You explored a metric in detail, adjusted the query to fit your needs, and saved it to a dashboard for ongoing monitoring.



As a next step, consider adding an alert or sharing this dashboard with your team.
